Q17: I don’t think it is ever possible for neural techniques (including LLMs) to produce AGI. It is definitely possible to deploy AI tools in situations where they are inappropriate (for example, a neural model directly controlling a vehicle).
Q18: I don’t think that LLMs accelerate (or even contribute to) the production of scientific knowledge. Also, it is implausible that they will lead to AGI.

Q1: Academic researcher in AI/ML/related field (e.g. PhD student, postdoc, professor)
Q5: Soon, but not as fast as possible
Q17: I've been involved in discussions about the AI control problem (as it was known back then) for almost two decades! Even before I started my formal education. Back then, I thought it was something very concerning. Now, I realize how far off we really are from understanding what underlies our own consciousness, much less being able to create conscious machines. I think it's very unlikely that the current generation of autoregressive models will come close to what we call 'general intelligence'. Look at how difficult it is to control model "hallucination" (a brilliant marketing term, I'll admit). That said, the tools in their current form are plenty capable of causing significant economic disruption due to job displacement and I think people might be underestimating that a bit. But we very are much in the peak of the hype cycle, and this survey is proof of it.
Q18: Framing it as simple as "OOM-level improvements in X-years" smells strongly of the same bullshit thinking that Kurzweil used in his books, where you extrapolate Moore's law and figure that once we have the same number of transistors on a chip as neurons in the brain, then we will have human-level intelligence. There have been many essays written on those aren't cogent arguments.

Q1: AI safety researcher or professional
Q5: Soon, but not as fast as possible
Q17:
Things along the lines of:
- China doesn't care about AI x-risk.
- We are surely on an exponentially worse track with AI x-risk if China gets AGI first.
- The world will almost surely become a dystopia if China gets AGI first.
etc
(To be clear, I think weaker version of those statements are plausible, e.g. the world is somewhat more likely to become a dystopia if China gets AGI first, but I think most Western people's beliefs on how much worse China is in terms of AI safety are WAY TOO disproportionate.)
Q18: I would be extremely surprised if robustly tamperproofing open models turned out to be technically feasible.

Q17: The statement that we cannot “easily restrain it”. As long as it’s contained in silicon form, we can easily shut it down. And of course, facilities of high importance like nuclear bases, should have a very restricted communication protocol (as it is now btw).

Q1: Academic researcher in AI/ML/related field (e.g. PhD student, postdoc, professor)
Q5: We should develop more powerful and more general systems as fast as possible
Q17: That the biggest risk is biological warfare, or cyber-security or other. I see the biggest threat as economical, in that if the holders of capital require less workers, wealth inequality will increasingly get worse, however as a consequence, the consumers are poorer, thus leading to companies that are vastly more efficient, and yet have no one to sell their produce to. What the solution to this problem is I do not know.
Q18: They extrapolate naively from a graph/set of datapoints. Anyone with a scientific brain knows that you simply cannot do that. Trends are not indicitave of the future, and cannot be used to predict the future, otherwise I would be a very rich man investing in the stock market. If you used this logic for moores law for example, eventually we would create sub-planck length transistors, and this thinking assumes the underlying model doesn't have a plateau or other that might inhibit or completely stop progress.

Q1: Academic researcher in AI/ML/related field (e.g. PhD student, postdoc, professor)
Q5: We should develop more powerful and more general systems as fast as possible
Q17: Intelligence and Autonomy are orthogonal. Current LLMs have a broad understanding, but lack depth and the reasoning abilities required to synthesise new knowledge. LLMs are non-agential and have no intrinsic motivations or objectives.

Q5: Eventually, but not soon.

Q1: Academic researcher in AI/ML/related field (e.g. PhD student, postdoc, professor)
Q5: Soon, but not as fast as possible
Q17: That it will be some kind of apocalyptic event, but is far more likely going to be a slow relinquishing of control and agency of the human race to a few optimisation algorithms who are misaligned with what humans actually want and need out of life. Or, much like recommendation algorism of social media and the Internet, use simple psychological techniques and hooks that it has learnt from data to make humans easier to predict and optimise their environment (us) in order to minimise their loss function/optimise their misaligned objectives.
Q18: "There is cause for optimism, if we understand that this issue is an intrinsic part of AI, much as containment is an intrinsic part of modern nuclear fusion research. The world need not be headed for grief." As we can see from Chernobyl and 3 mile island accidents, containment is only an intrinsic part of modern nuclear research due to public pressure and failure when it didn't use to be the case. Ignoring malicious human actors (which we shouldn't but, for the sake of argument, let's assume there aren't any) if building AGI becomes a race, then more difficult safety concerns will be discarded in the hope that a given team will get to the minimum viable AGI before anyone else, allowing for a misaligned AGI loose onto the world. Not to mention that safety research might be difficult to communicate or be counter to economic interests of powerful groups, such as the climate change issue we are currently facing causing a repeat of the same distrust in science and research related to safety. All of this is assuming that AGI will just lead to something akin to a company run by an AGI with misaligned goals, whereas the exponential take off could also be a (remote) possibility; where we only invent AGI once, and so the need for it to be understood and aligned is even more paramount!

Q1: Academic researcher in AI/ML/related field (e.g. PhD student, postdoc, professor)
Q5: Eventually, but not soon.
Q17: AI can have several unintended consequences that are not fully understood or researched enough. It is simple enough to have something to fall to the general public or into malicious hands and put us into a path of destruction. For instance, AI can be easily weaponized in international conflicts (e.g., war) or for misinformation purposes (e.g., elections). And if AI can be the central piece to overthrow any government, it's evidence enough it can be catastrophic.
Q18: The premise that one can control which training data people will use is overly optimistic

Q1: Academic researcher in AI/ML/related field (e.g. PhD student, postdoc, professor)
Q5: Eventually, but not soon.
Q17: The biggest misconception comes from people assuming that those warning of catastrophic AI risk are talking exclusively about LLMs.
Q18: The most implausible bit was the director of EleutherAI claiming that the problem can be fixed by filtering the dataset. That may be true for current day LLMs, but future AI systems may be able to make significant inferences from their training data, so that an AI trained on physics, chemistry and biology may be able to make reasonable estimated on how to out this together to build dangerous weapons, or at least give ideas on how to build and test them. AI risk may not always mean risk from LLMs, and definitely not from only LLMs of current day sophistication.
